headline.main: Adding Cumin to the Curry: A Matter of Life and Death

docs.abstract: Cornell University researchers report that people who live in hot climates may like hot foods because spice plants contain powerful antibiotic chemicals capable of killing or suppressing bacteria and fungi that commonly contaminate and spoil foods and can poison those who eat them; spices that are prominent in traditional dishes from tropical and subtropical regions are used with much lighter hand, if at all, in countries and regions where climate is colder; chart compares use of various hot foods and spices in India and Norway (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: CHOOSE any and all correct statements: People living in hot climates eat lots of highly seasoned foods because -- 1. Hot spices cool them down by making them sweat.
docs.snippet: CHOOSE any and all correct statements: People living in hot climates eat lots of highly seasoned foods because --    1. Hot spices cool them down by making them sweat.

headline.main: Executive Says He's Uncertain About Tobacco's Harm

docs.abstract: Philip Morris Cos chairman and chief executive Geoffrey C Bible, testifying in trial of State of Minnesota against tobacco companies, says even though everyone else believes cigarettes kill, he is not sure and does not want to know; says he does not believe cigarettes cause cancer, although smoking is very significant risk factor for disease (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone else may believe that cigarettes kill, the world's chief cigarette maker testified today, but he isn't sure. And he said he didn't want to know. ''I don't know. I just don't know,'' said Geoffrey C. Bible, chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris Companies, testifying in the trial of the State of Minnesota against tobacco companies. ''I believe everyone in the world believes that smoking causes disease. I don't know. There may be others who agree with me.''

headline.main: Live Music's Glory Days Pass It By; Suburbs Are Tuning Out, Even at Springsteen's Old Haunt

docs.abstract: Promoters and musicians say live music, once staple of bars, clubs and hotel lounges across New York City metropolitan area, is not drawing adult crowds anymore outside New York City; increasingly strict drinking and smoking laws have discouraged adults from frequenting clubs like Stone Pony in Asbury Park, NJ; noise complaints have forced many clubs to play softer music and close earlier; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: The band was jamming gleefully. The fans were dancing tirelessly. It was just like old times at the Stone Pony, the murky rock club where Bruce Springsteen got his start -- except for one thing. The only adults to be found were bartenders, bouncers and parents watching over the teen-age throngs. Which meant the Stone Pony, like most clubs that have managed to survive outside New York City, was not making money from liquor sales on this recent Friday night. Which meant the famous old haunt was one step closer to shutting its doors for good.
